ToolTip: Abbreviation or code representing the country.
Percentage of land area used for agricultural purposes.
Size of the armed forces in the country.
Number of births per 1,000 population per year.
International calling code for the country.
Name of the capital or major city.
Carbon dioxide emissions in tons.
Total distance of country boundary that touches coastline, in km.
Consumer Price Index, a measure of inflation and purchasing power.
Currency code used in the country.
The number of deaths per 1,000 population per year.
Population density measured in persons per square kilometer.
Top 3 countries or entities with which the country engages in significant export trade.
Average number of children born to a woman during her lifetime.
Percentage of land area covered by forests.
Price of gasoline per liter in local currency.
Gross Domestic Product, the total value of goods and services produced in the country.
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita, which represents the average wealth per person in the country.
The highest point in the country, usually measured in meters above sea level.
Number of deaths per 1,000 live births before reaching one year of age.
The two-letter country code used in internet domain names governed by the country.
Percentage of the country's population that uses the internet.
Total land area of the country in square kilometers.
Indicates whether the country is entirely surrounded by land and has no coastline.
Name of the country's largest city.
Latitude coordinate of the country's location.
Average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
Percentage of the population aged 15 and over who can read and write.
Longitude coordinate of the country's location.}
Number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.
The age that divides the population into two numerically equal groups, with half being younger and half older.
Minimum wage level in local currency.
The dominant religion or faith tradition practiced in the country.
Percentage of the population that is considered obese.
Official language(s) spoken in the country.
Percentage of total health expenditure paid out-of-pocket by individuals.
Number of physicians per thousand people.
Total population of the country.
Percentage of the population living below the poverty line.
Percentage of the population that is part of the labor force.
Gross enrollment ratio for primary education, per one thousand persons.
A neighboring country that shares a border with the country, selected randomly.
Tax revenue as a percentage of GDP.
Total value of goods and services exported by the country in a given period.
Overall tax burden as a percentage of commercial profits.
Percentage of the labor force that is unemployed.
Percentage of the population living in urban areas.
